title: 109_s645
content: The Act titled "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2005" restricts the manufacture, transfer, and possession of certain semiautomatic assault weapons. The Act "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2005" prohibits the manufacture, transfer, or possession of semiautomatic assault weapons, with exceptions for certain firearms and government entities. The Act prohibits the manufacture, transfer, or possession of semiautomatic assault weapons, with exceptions for government entities and law enforcement officers. The Act prohibits the manufacture, transfer, or possession of semiautomatic assault weapons, with exceptions for government entities, law enforcement officers, licensed manufacturers, and licensed importers for testing or experimentation authorized by the Secretary. It is unlawful to transfer a semiautomatic assault weapon except through a licensed dealer or a State or local law enforcement agency following specific procedures. The Attorney General must maintain records of semiautomatic assault weapons used in crimes and submit an annual report to Congress. The definition of a semiautomatic assault weapon is provided in the amended Section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code. The Attorney General must maintain records of semiautomatic assault weapons used in crimes and submit an annual report to Congress. The list of rifles or duplicates includes AK, AR-10, AR-15, Calico Liberty, Dragunov, FN/FAL, Hi-Point Carbine, HK-91, Kel-Tec Sub Rifle, M1 Carbine, Saiga, SKS, SLG 95, SLR 95 or 96. The list of banned firearms includes SLG 95, SLR 95 or 96, Steyr AUG, Sturm, Ruger Mini-14, Tavor, Thompson 1927, Thompson M1, Uzi, Calico M-110, MAC-10, MAC-11, Olympic Arms OA, TEC-9, TEC-DC9, TEC-22 Scorpion, AB-10, Armscor 30 BG, SPAS 12, and LAW 12. The banned firearms list includes Armscor 30 BG, SPAS 12, LAW 12, Striker 12, semiautomatic rifles with detachable magazines and specific features, semiautomatic rifles with fixed magazines over 10 rounds capacity, and semiautomatic pistols. The banned firearms list includes semiautomatic pistols with detachable magazines and specific features, semiautomatic pistols with fixed magazines over 10 rounds capacity, and semiautomatic shotguns with various features like folding or telescoping stocks and pistol grips. The banned firearms list includes semiautomatic pistols with detachable magazines and specific features, fixed magazine capacity of more than 5 rounds, shotguns with revolving cylinders, frames or receivers based on specified firearms, conversion kits, and military or law enforcement weapons not suitable for sporting purposes. The legislation prohibits certain firearms not suitable for sporting purposes, with penalties for violations and additional identification markings for semiautomatic assault weapons. Section 923(i) of title 18, United States Code is amended to require the serial number of any semiautomatic assault weapon manufactured after a certain date to show the manufacturing date. Additionally, related definitions such as "barrel shroud" and "conversion kit" are provided in the legislation. The legislation provides definitions for key terms related to firearms, including "detachable magazine," "fixed magazine," "folding or telescoping stock," and "forward grip." These definitions are crucial in determining the characteristics of semiautomatic assault weapons. The legislation defines terms like "pistol grip" and "threaded barrel" in relation to firearms. The legislation defines terms related to firearms, including "pistol grip" and "threaded barrel." Additionally, it includes a ban on large capacity ammunition feeding devices. The legislation prohibits the transfer or possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices, with exceptions for devices lawfully possessed before the enactment. It also bans the importation of such devices into the United States. The legislation prohibits the transfer or possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices, with exceptions for specific purposes such as law enforcement use, nuclear facility security, and authorized testing by licensed manufacturers or importers. The legislation prohibits the transfer of large capacity ammunition feeding devices manufactured before a certain date unless certified to the Attorney General within 60 days. Large capacity ammunition feeding devices are defined as devices that can hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition. The legislation prohibits the transfer of large capacity ammunition feeding devices that can hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition. These devices must have identification markings including a serial number indicating they were manufactured after a certain date. The Attorney General can regulate the transfer of assault weapons with large capacity ammunition feeding devices. Violators face fines and up to 10 years in prison. The Attorney General will conduct a study to investigate the impact of the Act and its amendments on violent and drug trafficking crime over 18 months. A report detailing the findings will be submitted to Congress within 30 months of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Act addresses unlawful weapons transfers to juveniles. SEC. 5. UNLAWFUL WEAPONS TRANSFERS TO JUVENILES: Amends Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code to include semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment.
